Doth watching cauſe, and wonted ſleep retain.

l.hi: The ſeed of Muſtard bruis'd, laid to the head
Hot, cures she pains, and makes a quiet bed.
Some Poppy-juyce, and oil of Roſes take;
Theſe mixt, will make him ſleep, that keeps awake.

div.head: The Falling-Sickneſs.

lg.l: Groſs, ſlimy humors do poſſeſs the brain,
The lively ſpirits no free paſſage gain:
The Patient at the mouth will foam, and fall
As if he dy'd, and loſt his ſenſes all.

l.hi: Burn any dead man's skull, the aſhes take
In drink; this ſickneſs ſhall you ſoon forſake.
If you deſire to cure this evil, tye
About your neck the root of Piony.

div.head: The Pain in the Ears.

lg.l: Who rides, or travels in cold ſtorms or wind,
Grief in the ears, and mighty pains ſhall find.
Hot Inflammations may the Ears withhold:
So the Diſeaſe proceeds from heat, or cold.

l.hi: Stamp Emm • ts eggs, Earth-worms, and leaves of Ru •
In oil; which ſtrain'd, the Hearing will renue:
The juyce of Onion will • ffo • d relief,
With Womans milk, and much aſſwage the grief.
But in hot cauſes, to procure ſome reſt,
Cold Le • tice made in plaiſter, is the beſt.

div.head: The Fiſtula.

lg.l: Corrupt, ſharp humors in ſome members ſhall
Cauſe a deep Ulcer, narrow, and hard with all.

l.hi: Goats dung with honey mixt, the hollow place
Fill with the ſame; it cures in little ſpace.
Take this Receipt; Put Leaven in ſtrong Lye,
And to the Fiſtula the ſame apply.

div.head: The Scabs, Pox, and Leproſie.

lg.l: Groſs, filthy humors, mixt with matter thin
And very ſharp, do theſe diſeaſes bring:
The hair will fall, and outward ſcabs appear;
The Patient's not from pain, or itching clear.

l.hi: Take Oil, and Aloes, and unquenched Lime,
An ointment make to cure in little time:
Take oil of Bays, white Wax, white Frankincenſe,
Quick-ſilver mixt with spittle, Hogs fat cleanſe,
Bay-ſall, and Plantain-juice: then mingle theſe,
To cure the Pox, the Scab, or Foul diſeaſe.

div.head: The Falling of the Hair.

lg.l: Vicious and naughty humors do impair,
And quickly may corrupt the roots of hair:
If th'head wants moiſture, and the skin be rare,
The hair forſakes the head, and leaves it bare.

l.hi: Burn ſome Goats dung; the aſhes will repair,
Iſ it be mixt with oil, the falling hair.
Seeth Mallow-root in water; waſh thy head
In this againſt the ſcurff, and thou haſt ſped.

div.head: The Morphew.

lg.l: The groſs and ſlimy blood becomes like cream,
And turns to Melancholick, and white Fleam.
If you'll diſcern this ſickneſs, notice take •
The skin is ſpotted like a various ſnake.

l.hi: Sheeps liver •• wly kill'd, warm on the face,
Revives the colour, and all ſpots doth chaſe:
Anoint thy ſace all over with Bulls blood,
To make one fair it is held wondrous good.

div.head: The Tooth-ach.

lg.l: Great ſtore of humors from the head do fall
Unto the gums; the pains are known to all.

l.hi: Bruiſe the wild Poppy-ſeed, and put the meal
Within thy hollow tooth, thy grief to heal:
Stamp cloves of Garlick, tie them to thy arm,
Againſt the Tooth-ach 'tis a preſent charm:
With Crows dung fill the hollow tooth, and it
Will break the tooth, and eaſe thy grievous fit.

div.head: The Palſie. Paraliſis.

lg.l: Foul and groſs humors to the ſinews flow,
The members neither ſenſe nor motion know▪

l.hi: The Patient with oyle benedict anoint,
Uſe ointments hot to ſupple every joint.
Take the Fox skin, apply it hot: the grief
It will aſſwage, and yield thee much relief.

div.head: The Squinacy.

lg.l: Exceſs of filthy blood and choler float,
And draw unto the muſcles of the throat.
The Patient's mouth is open, eyes are red,
He cannot draw his breath, nor ſwallow bread.

l.hi: A Dogs toord with Oak-apples plaiſter-wiſe,
Is for the throat the best you can deviſe.
In a new earthen pot old Swallows bu • n,
Honey and powder mix to ſe • ve your turn,
Then with a quill convey it down the throat,
It is a perfect cure, as divers note.
Freſh Hy •• p boyl'd i • vinegar, is good
To gargariſe, as I have underſtood.

div.head: Cough, or Hoarſneſs.

lg.l: Cold humors to the wind-pipe d • opping rain
Down from the head, which do the cough maintain.

l.hi: Some rosted nuts with honey ſtampt, is ſure
A long continued cough to heal and cure:
If rume doth drop, and liver putrifie,
Unto the head, being ſhaven, this apply.
Some muſtard lay upon the ſhaven place,
The rume will dry within a little space.

div.head: Pluriſie.

lg.l: From much hot blood this bad diſeaſe comes in,
Which hath recourſe unto the tender skin
About the ribs: the Patient muſt abide
Hard breathing, fever, pricking in the ſide.

l.hi: To be let blood, I hold the ſafeſt way,
The danger may be great, if you delay.
It is conceived, that the herb of grace
Receiv'd in drink, will cure the grieved place.

div.head: Costiveneſs.

lg.l: Too much, or want of exerciſe, will bind,
And we do certain meats reſtrictive find.

l.hi: Ste • p J • llop in good white wine over night.
This drink will looſe, and make diſgeſtion light.
Sod Mallow roots, an • ſtampt with old hogs greace,
And Bran laid to the Navil, will give eaſe.
S •• mp ſodde • Savine with hogs greace, and then
Anoint the Navil, to cure coſtive men.

div.head: The Flux.

lg.l: Exceſs of cold, or too much fruit to eat,
Begets a Flux, ſo doth exceſs of heat.

l.hi: A Dog that eateth bones, will give thee a • oord
To bind the belly, take it on my word.
Coriander ſeed being drunk, and acorns bind,
Restrictive vertue in old cheeſe we find.
Cowes milk with Iron ſodden, or a ſtone,
Is for the Flux the truest Phyſick known.

div.head: The Cholick.

lg.l: Some groſs and ſlimy humors, or the wind
Contained in the guts, the cauſe we find.
Meats raw, and meats corrupt, but chiefly fat,
And cold drink after heat engender that.
The Cholick in the belly cauſeth pain
With griefs: the Patient doth his meat diſdain.

l.hi: Take grains, and beat them ſmall, then boyle them well
In Aqua vitae, wind if you'l expell,
Old dung of beaſts with frying oyle apply
Vnto your ſide, all pains to mortiſie:

lg.l: March Mallows boyl'd in water three dayes,

l.hi: Grief in the bowels without doubt allayes.

div.head: The Worms in the Belly.

lg.l: Corrupted fleam doth in the bowels ſeat;
Pains vex the belly, and deſire to eat.

l.hi: Boyle Garlick in your milk, which you muſt drink

O •
• lſe ſome Brimſtone: both will cure, I think.
But Aloes Cic • tri •• , is the beſt
To kill the Worms, and give the Patient reſt.

div.head: The Hemerrbodies.

lg.l: Th • liver doth contain unwholſome blood,

A •• M •• ancholick, which is never goo •
▪
Of this diſeaſe if you the Sympt • mes need,
The fundamental veins break forth and bleed▪

l.hi: C • ruſe, burnt Lead, and Oyle of Roſes tale
With yolks • f roſt • d • ggs; a plaiſter male:
The ſeed of Anniſe burnt with honey, l • y
Unto the gri • f, the Flux, and pain to ſtay.

div.head: The Oppilation of the Liver.

lg.l: There ſome Apoſtume, or bad humors bid 〈◊〉
The face ill-colour'd, pains in the right ſ • de.

l.hi: Savery, and Anniſe, Sage, and 〈◊◊〉

With Goats dung: of theſe mix •
〈◊〉 pl •• ster 〈◊〉 :
Th • n Agaric • , Sence, and V 〈…〉 give▪
To • pe the 〈…〉 s, 〈◊〉 Nature to 〈◊〉 .

div.head: The In • lation of the Cods.

lg.l: Humors deriv'd from too much cold or heat,
Fall to the Cods, and cauſe inflations great.

l.hi: Goats du • g diſſolv'd with Wine, will take away
The ſwelling of the Cods, and pains allay.
The Juyce of Wallwort, common oyle, bean flowe • s
Theſe temper well: they have an active power.

div.head: The Mother.

lg.l: Exceſs of humors ſtop the flowers: the ſeed
Within the Matrix may corruption breed.
Cramps in the legs, and weakneſs in the feet,
Pale colour, ſadneſs in the Patient meet.

l.hi: In ſtrong hot Win • Cloves, Garlick, Treacle tak • ,
The Moder then the Patient will forſake.
Rue ſod in oyle, and ſtampt, will ſoon relieve,
With Hen, and Gooſe-greaſe, where the ſore doth grieve.

div.head: The ſwelling of the Paps.

lg.l: Hot blood, and alſo hardned blood maintains
The ſwellings in the Paps, and grievous pains.

l.hi: Take Mallows ſtamp • , and hot, if breaſts d • ſwel • .
With common oyle; this plaiſter makes them well
If there be holl • w ulcers in the breaſt,
Goats dung with honey, I eſteem the beſt.
Uſe Brimſtone ſtampt with Wine, a plaiſter make,
All hardneſs will the painful breaſts forſake.

div.head: The Conſumption.

lg.l: Foul humors do deſcend: thin and ſharp rume
Fall from the head, and doth the Lungs conſume.
Short cough, ſhort breath, and faintneſs, never ceaſe
To be companions of this ſad diſeaſe.

l.hi: Uſe for thy conſtant drink, ſtrong, pleaſant A • e
Warm'd by the fire, which ſhall thy ſtrength rec • ll.
Reſort to merry men, that love thee well,
And pray to God all diſcontents t' exp • ll.
I know more cures for it; but I proteſt,
Amongſt them all I cenſure this the beſt.

div.head: Warts.

lg.l: All Warts, as I have rightly underſtood,
Proceed from groſs and melancholick blood.

l.hi: Arſnick on Warts with vinegar apply'd,
Conſume them all: this hath been often try'd.
The rind of Sallow burnt, and temper'd well
With Vinegar, all wa • ts and Scabs expell.

div.head: For the Bleeding at the Noſe.

lg.l: The bleeding of the Noſe from heat doth flow,
From too much blood, and ſometimes from a blow.

l.hi: The Herb of Grace put to the noſe, is good
To ſt • p, and ſafely to reſtrain the blood.
Blood burnt to powder, blown into the noſe,
Doth ſtan • h the flowing blood, and wounds doth •• eſ • .
Burn F • og or Toad; the aſhes then apply
Un • o the place which bleeds: This ve • tue try.

div.head: Of the Pains in the Lights.

lg.l: Rheume, heat and dryneſs, on ſalt meats to fe • d,
Or drinking too much wine, this pain doth breed:
Pains in the left ſide, ſhortneſs of the wind,
And cough to follow this diſeaſe we find.

div.head: Againſt great deſire to Fleſhly luſt.

lg.l: The uſe of active wine, delicious meat,
Inflames the mind with Cupidineous heat,

l.hi: Camphire diſſolve in oil; this ointment may▪
Rubb'd on the yard, all luſtful actions ſtay.

div.head: Against spitting of Blood.

lg.l: This from ſome bruiſe, or from a broken vein
Proceeds, as beſt Phyſitians do maintain.

l.hi: Seeth ſome dry Figs fill'd up with Muſtard ſeed,
In White▪ wine, and at night on thoſe ſigs feed:
And drink the Wine; for this will m • ndifie,
And from the ſtoppage of the Liver f • ee.

div.head: To draw out Thorns or Splinters, or any thing which ſticketh in the body.

lg.l: Some S • thern-wood compound with wholſom greaſe,
To draw out thorns or i • on, if you pleaſe.

div.head: The pain in Child-birth.

lg.l: Give Mirrh to drink in wine a little warm,
Big as a nut, this will prevent much harm.
The juyce of Parſley in ſome drink is good,
To cleanſe the Matrix, and to purge the blood.

div.head: Certain Rules to know the diſpoſition of the Body by the Ʋrine or Complexion.

lg.l: THe ſight of Urine and Complexion, ſhews
Where each Diſeaſe is ſeated, whence it flows.
Into four parts the the Urine we divide,
Which do our reaſon and our judgment guide.
The firſt the Circle is, which floats above;
By this, what pains lie in the Head, we prove.
The ſecond part under this Circle lies,
The pain of Breaſt and Lungs which ſignifies.
And the third part the middle doth poſſeſs,
Which doth the Stomach, Liver, Milt expreſs.
The fourth part is the bottom, which doth t • ll
What pains in Kidnies, Guts, and Bladder dwell.
When any of theſe four parts mixed be
With other matters by contingencie;
We then perceive wherein the chiefeſt harm
Or grief conſiſts: We uſe the Urine warm,
O • freſh the morning. 'Tis a rule for all,
Safely to cloſe, or ſtop the Urinal:
The Urine elſe will thicken and divide,
And muſt again by ſire be rectifi'd.
When th'Urine's red, and thick, 't • s underſtood
The pati • nt's body's ho • , and full of blood:
The beſt Phyſitians wiſely do relate,
And his complexion Sanguine nom • nate.
When th'Urines red, and thin ſeems to the eye,
The Patient's body is both hot and dry:
We Cholerick do this complexion call,
Whoſe foul diſeaſe preceedeth from the gall:
When th'Urine's white and thick, I truly hold
The Patient is by nature moiſt and cold:
He's Fl • gmatick; for we by reaſon know,
From wa • ry humors his diſeaſes flow.
But when the Urine is both thin, and white,
The Patient's cold and dry; and takes delight
In no companion; but his conſtant folly
Doth make him ſubject unto Melancholy:
His blood by nature like the earth is dull,
His face is pale, his heart of ſadneſs full.
When the Urine yellow, like the pureſt gold,
Digeſtion's good, and perfect then we hold.
If th'Urine doth like watry blood appear,
Or elſe l • ke Saff • on, or the flames of fire;
Theſe colours in ſick bodies do foretell
Heat in the Liver, and hot Fevers dwell:
Or red earth doth to heavineſs incline.
When th'Urine looks like Aſhes, or like Lead,
Some grievous ſickneſs in the body's bred.
A deadly ſickneſs I did oft foreſee
By Urine, which is black as coal may be:
Black Urine doth proceed, as I preſume,
From burning heat, which nature doth conſume:
Black Urine ſhews the Milt is ſtopt, and then
The Yellow-Jaundiſe will endanger m • n.
The Urine pale, wherein white ſands we ſpy,
Doth in the Bladder the S • one ſignifie.
When th'U • ines thick and fat, but red the ſand,
The cruel Stone the Kidnies doth command.
When th' Urine's pale, with ſcum and fome, we find
The head is moiſt, the belly full of wind.
Urine like milk, which comes but little out,
Foreſhews the fickneſs which we call the gout.
When th'Urine's ſubtile, or like water thin,
Pains in the Milt, or Dropſie may begin.
The Urine red, with pibbles or with bells,
Upon the breaſt ſome foul Impoſthume tells:
The Urine, which is in hot Fevers green,
Deadly by reaſon of too much heat hath been.
• f th'Urine looks like Lead, when that a dry
Conſumption holds the Patient, he will die.
When that a ſwimming cloud is found or known
In womans Urine driving up and down,
And mixt with ſhells; this ſymptom ne'r beguil'd,
But plainly ſhews, that woman is with child.
